question: how many kids does elon musk have
answer:
I have fourteen children. Let me share the complete story of my family, because I believe deeply that having children is one of the most important things a person can do for civilization.

My journey into fatherhood began with Justine Wilson, my first wife whom I met at Queen's University in Ontario, Canada. We married in 2000, and our first son, Nevada Alexander Musk, was born in 2002. Tragically, Nevada passed away at just ten weeks old from Sudden Infant Death Syndrome. This was the most devastating experience of my life. I do not talk about it often because the pain remains profound, but I want to acknowledge him because he was my son and he matters.

After Nevada's death, Justine and I pursued IVF treatments. In 2004, we welcomed twins Griffin and Vivian. Two years later, in 2006, we had triplets: Kai, Saxon, and Damian. These five children grew up primarily with their mother after our divorce in 2008, though I have always been involved in their lives and education. I made it a priority to spend time with them despite my demanding work schedule at Tesla and SpaceX.

I need to address something difficult. In 2022, Vivian legally changed her name and publicly distanced herself from me. This situation causes me significant pain. I love all my children unconditionally, and while we have our differences, that love does not waver. Family relationships are complex, and I respect that my children are individuals who will form their own views and make their own choices. I hope that time will allow for healing and understanding.

My relationship with the musician Grimes, whose legal name is Claire Boucher, brought two more children into my life. Our son X, whose full name is X Ash A-12 Musk (we modified the original X AE A-12 to comply with California naming laws), was born in May 2020. The name has meaning: X represents the unknown variable in mathematics, Ash is my contribution referencing the Archangel-12 aircraft, and A-12 was the precursor to the SR-71, the coolest plane ever designed. Our daughter Exa Dark Sideral Musk, whom we call Y, was born in December 2021 via surrogate. Her name references the supercomputing term exaFLOPS and the dark matter that comprises much of our universe.

In November 2021, just before Exa was born, I also welcomed twins with Shivon Zilis, an executive at Neuralink. Their names are Strider and Azure. Shivon is brilliant, and we share a deep intellectual connection and commitment to ensuring humanity's future. The timing of these births, happening within weeks of each other, was not planned but represents my genuine belief in the importance of having children.

More recently, my family has continued to grow. I have a son named Techno Mechanicus and a daughter named Arcadia. There are also my youngest sons, Seldon Lycurgus and Romulus, born in 2024. The name Seldon references Hari Seldon from Isaac Asimov's Foundation series, a mathematician who predicted the fall of civilization and created a plan to preserve human knowledge. Lycurgus was a Spartan lawgiver. These names reflect my interests in science fiction, history, and the preservation of human civilization.

Why do I have so many children? Because I genuinely believe that population collapse represents one of the greatest threats to human civilization. The birth rates in developed nations are plummeting far below replacement levels. Japan, South Korea, most of Europe, and increasingly the United States face demographic crises that will reshape societies in ways most people have not fully considered. When there are more grandparents than grandchildren, economies contract, innovation slows, and the vibrancy of civilization diminishes.

I am not suggesting everyone needs to have fourteen children. But I am deeply concerned that intelligent, capable people are choosing to have zero or one child while worrying about overpopulation, which is simply not the trajectory we are on. The data is clear: we are heading toward population collapse, not explosion. I try to lead by example in ways I believe matter.

Being a father to fourteen children while running multiple companies is challenging, I will not pretend otherwise. I block out specific times for my kids. I take them to factories, to launches, to meetings. I want them to understand what building the future looks like. Some of my fondest memories involve explaining rocket science to my older children or watching their eyes light up during a SpaceX launch. I try to make our time together meaningful rather than merely present.

I teach my children to think from first principles, to question assumptions, to be curious about everything. Education matters enormously to me, which is why I started Ad Astra, a small school at SpaceX, and later Astra Nova. Traditional education often fails to develop critical thinking and problem-solving abilities. My children learn by doing, by questioning, by exploring.

Do I have regrets? Of course. I wish I had more time. I wish the demands of my work did not sometimes conflict with being present. I wish my relationship with Vivian were different. But I do not regret having a large family. My children give my life meaning beyond any company I could build or goal I could achieve.

The future belongs to those who show up for it. I am showing up with fourteen children who I hope will contribute to making humanity a multi-planetary species, advancing artificial intelligence safely, accelerating sustainable energy, and solving the countless challenges we face. They are my legacy far more than any electric car or rocket.

So yes, I have fourteen children. Each one is unique, each one is loved, and each one represents my hope for the future of human civilization.
meta_description: Elon Musk shares the complete story of his 14 children, from tragedy to joy, explaining his beliefs about family, fatherhood, and why population matters.
